result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Lyndy R. Lucas

records.addlTxt:
3:18 PM Defendant Lyndy R. Lucas appeared by video, in custody from Marquette County Jail.  Attorney Brian J. Juech appeared by video for State of Wisconsin. 
Defendant received a copy of the criminal complaint.  Court confirms address.  Defendant does not have a phone right now as she has been incarcerated for the last 4 months.  
Court advises defendant of right to an attorney.  Defendant understands and will call the PD office.
Court finds probable cause for the charge for Riverside purposes. 

Atty Juech has no objection to a signature bond with conditions. 
Defendant asks for a no contact with the victim
Atty Juech has no objection but he doesn't know how the jail will accommodate that.

BY THE COURT:  Court sets a $1,000 Signature bond with no special conditions.
Initial appearance scheduled for November 14, 2022 at 10:00 am.
Initial appearance on November 14, 2022 at 10:00 am.
